title: R40944
content: Copyright is the exclusive right to reproduce, distribute, perform, display, and exploit an original work of authorship. Protection is automatic when the work is created, but registration offers advantages such as the ability to file infringement suits and potentially receive statutory damages and attorney's fees. In a 2001 Supreme Court case, New York Times Co. v. Tasini, freelance authors sued publishers for licensing their articles to electronic databases without permission. The case focused on the copyright owner's exclusive right to reproduce and distribute their work. The Supreme Court ruled in New York Times Co. v. Tasini that publishers cannot reproduce freelance works electronically without specific authorization, leading to the removal of many freelance works from electronic databases. This decision required publishers to obtain a separate license from authors for electronic reproduction. Class action infringement suits were activated and consolidated in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York, including a fourth coordinated action. These claims make up the litigation discussed in the report, similar to the Tasini case. Reed Elsevier v. Muchnick is a class action lawsuit where named plaintiffs sue on behalf of a larger group with similar claims, protecting the interests of other class members. In Reed Elsevier v. Muchnick, class action litigation can proceed only after court certification, with settlement or dismissal requiring court approval. Plaintiffs include individual authors and trade groups representing freelance authors whose works were reproduced in electronic databases without compensation. The plaintiffs sued publishers and electronic database services for copyright infringement after their freelance works were reproduced without consent. The parties reached an agreement in 2005 after three years of negotiations, categorizing claims for compensation. The settlement in 2005 categorized claims for compensation into three categories based on the type of copyright infringement. Category A claims were eligible for statutory damages and attorney's fees, Category B claims qualified for actual damages only, and Category C claims mainly involved unregistered copyrights. Each category had a specific damages formula, with claimants receiving either a flat fee or a percentage of the original work's price. The settlement in 2005 categorized claims for compensation into three categories based on the type of copyright infringement, with claimants receiving either a flat fee or a percentage of the original work's price. If the total cost of claims exceeded $18 million, Category C claimants' payments could be reduced to zero before Category A and B claimants were affected, known as the "C-reduction." Plaintiffs agreed to release all claims against defendants in exchange for compensation, leading to a motion for class certification and settlement approval. Objectors opposed the motion for class certification and settlement approval, arguing that the settlement was unfair to Category C claimants who were paid little and singled out for reduction if total claims exceeded $18 million. They also contended that named plaintiffs with registered copyrights did not adequately represent absent class members with unregistered copyrights. Defendants argued that Category C claimants were fairly represented and treated under 17 U.S.C. §411(a). The district court granted final class certification and settlement approval in September 2005, despite objections regarding fairness and representation. The Second Circuit Court of Appeals raised concerns about jurisdiction over claims involving unregistered copyrights. The Second Circuit Court of Appeals raised concerns about subject-matter jurisdiction over claims concerning the infringement of unregistered copyrights, despite arguments from both plaintiffs and defendants that the Copyright Act's registration requirement is not jurisdictional. The court disagreed with the argument that jurisdiction is proper if a plaintiff brings a single claim based on a registered copyright, stating that the district court does not acquire jurisdiction over related claims from unregistered copyrights. The Second Circuit Court of Appeals disagreed with arguments that jurisdiction is proper for claims involving unregistered copyrights. The court noted that district courts derive jurisdiction in copyright actions from specific sections of Title 28 of the U.S. Code, supplemented by §411(a) of the Copyright Act, which limits jurisdiction over copyright infringement cases. The Second Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that copyright registration is a jurisdictional requirement for infringement suits, limiting district court jurisdiction to claims arising from registered copyrights only. This decision was based on previous opinions and distinguished from a Supreme Court ruling. The Second Circuit held that the district court lacked authority to certify the class and approve the settlement due to a jurisdictional defect, precluding supplemental jurisdiction. Judge Walker dissented, suggesting a re-evaluation of the copyright registration requirement as an enforcement mechanism rather than a rights-creating statute. The U.S. Supreme Court reviewed a case regarding whether 17 U.S.C. §411(a) restricts federal courts' jurisdiction over copyright infringement actions. The Second Circuit viewed the copyright registration requirement as an enforcement mechanism, not a rights-creating statute, allowing a class-action settlement to proceed despite some copyrights not being registered. §411(a) states that no civil action for copyright infringement of a U.S. work can be filed without copyright registration. If registration is refused, the applicant can still sue by serving notice to the Register of Copyrights. The Register can choose to join the action regarding the copyright claim's registrability. The issue of registrability of the copyright claim is debated in the case Reed Elsevier et al. Petitioners argue that the registration requirement in §411(a) is not a jurisdictional restriction but a mandatory prerequisite to sue. They claim that circuit courts have failed to implement the "bright line" test set by the Supreme Court in Arbaugh v. Y&H Corp. Petitioners argue that the registration requirement in §411(a) is not a jurisdictional restriction but a mandatory prerequisite to sue. They warn that the Second Circuit's characterization of §411(a) could hinder parties from settling disputes involving unregistered works. Respondents argue that §411(a) is a claim-processing rule, not a jurisdictional bar, and can be enforced or waived by defendants. They cite cases where the jurisdiction requirement was waived, and claim supplemental jurisdiction for Category-C authors with unregistered copyrights. The United States, as amicus curiae, supported vacatur of the Second Circuit's judgment, arguing that §411(a) does not limit federal courts' subject-matter jurisdiction but serves as a mandatory prerequisite to suit. District courts should enforce §411(a) sua sponte, and once a case reaches the court of appeals, the district court has jurisdiction. The U.S. argued that §411(a) should not be strictly applied in the court of appeals to avoid wasting judicial resources. Both parties wanted the Supreme Court to overturn the Second Circuit's ruling, leading to the appointment of an amicus curiae to support the judgment. Jones Merritt will serve as amicus curiae in support of the Second Circuit's judgment, arguing that §411(a) restricts federal court jurisdiction, serves public purposes, and cannot be waived by the parties. Professor Merritt argues that the judicial process prevents parties from waiving §411(a) jurisdictional bar, as both parties defended the fairness of their settlement. The Computer and Communications Industry Association (CCIA) also presented arguments against a special rule for settlement and supplemental jurisdiction act curing the jurisdictional defect in the case involving multiple authors and databases. The Computer and Communications Industry Association (CCIA) supported the Second Circuit's judgment, emphasizing the registration requirement as crucial for protecting Internet service providers from copyright claims. They argued that the petitioners' writ of certoriari should be dismissed due to the lack of a case or controversy before the court. The Supreme Court unanimously reversed the Second Circuit's judgment on March 2, 2010, ruling that §411(a) limits federal courts' subject-matter jurisdiction. CCIA urged the Court to dismiss the petitioners' writ due to the lack of a case or controversy. The Supreme Court ruled that the Copyright Act's registration requirement is not a limit on federal court jurisdiction for copyright infringement claims involving unregistered works. The district court had the authority to certify the class and approve the settlement between freelance authors, publishers, and electronic databases. The Supreme Court clarified that some statutory requirements are not jurisdictional conditions but rather claim-processing rules or elements of a cause of action. They referred to their approach in the 2006 Arbaugh v. Y & H Corp. decision to help federal courts distinguish between true jurisdictional conditions and nonjurisdictional rules. The Arbaugh Court clarified that statutory limitations on coverage should be treated as nonjurisdictional if Congress does not specify them as jurisdictional. In a sexual harassment case under Title VII, the Court held that the numerical qualification for "employer" was a substantive element of the claim for relief. The Arbaugh Court determined that the employee numerosity requirement for "employer" in Title VII claims was a substantive element of relief, not affecting federal court jurisdiction. This decision was based on the lack of clear jurisdictional language in Title VII and the separation of the numerosity requirement from jurisdiction-granting sections. The Reed Elsevier Court applied this precedent to §411(a) of the Copyright Act. The Court in Reed Elsevier rejected the argument that §411(a) of the Copyright Act is jurisdictional based on the presence of the word "jurisdiction." It clarified that the reference to "jurisdiction" was to establish federal court authority to determine registrability, regardless of the Register's involvement in the infringement suit. The Court in Reed Elsevier clarified that §411(a) of the Copyright Act does not condition federal court jurisdiction on copyright registration before suing for infringement. §411(a) allows exceptions to the registration requirement for infringement claims. The Court clarified that §411(a) of the Copyright Act does not require copyright registration for federal court jurisdiction in infringement claims involving unregistered works, except in specific circumstances. The Reed Elsevier Court distinguished its 2007 decision in Bowles v. Russell regarding statutory conditions for initiating a lawsuit, emphasizing the jurisdictional nature of certain requirements. The Reed Elsevier Court clarified that §411(a)'s registration requirement is not jurisdictional, unlike the statutory time limit in Bowles v. Russell. The Court rejected arguments to construe §411(a) as jurisdictional for policy goals and congressional objectives. The Court clarified that §411(a)'s registration requirement is not jurisdictional, rejecting arguments based on policy goals and congressional objectives. The Court also declined to affirm the appellate court's judgment on estoppel grounds. The Supreme Court clarified that §411(a)'s registration requirement is not jurisdictional, rejecting arguments based on policy goals and congressional objectives. The Court also declined to affirm the appellate court's judgment on estoppel grounds, as it did not adopt petitioners' interpretation of § 411(a) and expressed no opinion on the fairness, reasonableness, or adequacy of the settlement. The Supreme Court will consider the merits and objections of the settlement in a copyright infringement case. The Court did not decide if §411(a) is a mandatory requirement for filing a claim, leaving it open for lower courts to interpret. Justice Ginsburg agreed that §411(a) should be a precondition for filing a claim but noted it does not limit federal court jurisdiction. Justice Ginsburg discussed the tension between Arbaugh and Bowles precedents regarding federal court jurisdiction. She highlighted the need for statutory conditions to be explicitly labeled as jurisdictional by Congress. Justice Ginsburg reconciled the tension between Arbaugh and Bowles precedents on federal court jurisdiction, emphasizing the need for statutory conditions to be explicitly labeled as jurisdictional by Congress. She argued that §411(a) is nonjurisdictional as it does not speak in jurisdictional terms or refer to the jurisdiction of district courts, contrary to over 200 opinions characterizing it as such. Justice Ginsburg argued that Bowles does not apply to the Copyright Act's registration requirement due to the lack of Supreme Court opinions on the matter. The Reed Elsevier case is remanded to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit to review the settlement's merits. If approved, freelance authors will receive compensation and databases can restore publications. The appellate court may focus on objections to the damages formula. Judge Walker's dissent to the Second Circuit's ruling in the Reed Elsevier case raises concerns about the settlement's damages formula, particularly the lack of a sub-class for "C-class" claim holders. Objectors argue that the named representatives, who hold more "A-class" and "B-class" claims, may show favoritism towards those claims, leaving C-class claim holders with little or no compensation. The Supreme Court's opinion in Reed Elsevier impacts copyright holders in future infringement cases, allowing unregistered works to participate in settlements and lawsuits. District courts may dismiss copyright claims for unregistered works, while also reaffirming the importance of registration. The Reed Elsevier case impacts copyright law by allowing unregistered works to be included in infringement claims and settlements. It also clarifies federal courts' jurisdiction on copyright infringement class actions involving both registered and unregistered works. The case reaffirms the importance of registration in copyright law litigation.
